channel.title: Window Manager summary (Flux, Gnome, KDE)
channel.description:
The three most popular window managers are Fluxbox, Gnome, and KDE. Whichever you choose is just a matter of personal preference. Here's a few details about each one to stop all this bullshit about window managers. In order of resources used, Flux is by far the lightest, followed by Gnome, with KDE using the most resources.
[size=10pt][b]Gnome[/b][/size] Gnome is a fairly lightweight window manager. It's simplistic and doesn't really have many resource-guzzling effects. [b]Screenshots:[/b] [url=http://www.ubuntux.org/files/images/Screenshot.preview.png]Gnome on Ubuntu[/url] [url=http://paradigma.pt/~vd/wlog/images/gnome-2.12/Screenshot-2.png]Another Gnome on Ubuntu[/url] [url=http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/djst/photos/2005-01-20/gentoo-gnome.png]Gnome on Gentoo[/url]
[size=10pt][b]KDE[/b][/size] KDE has a lot more features then gnome, and thus uses more system resources, which is fine provided you have them to spare :p [b]Screenshots:[/b] [url=http://www.kubuntu.org/images/katapult.png]KDE on Ubuntu (Kubuntu)[/url] [url=http://www.gentoo.pl/~arsen/screens/kde/kde20051103.png]KDE on Gentoo[/url]
[size=10pt][b]Fluxbox[/b][/size] Fluxbox is amazingly lightweight and very configurable. Perfect if you don't have much RAM. [b]Screenshots:[/b] [url=http://www.halbmoendli.ch/files/images/screenshot.jpg]Fluxbox on Ubuntu[/url] [url=http://forum.linux.be/gfx.use/linux.screenshot.1379.1.png]Fluxbox on Gentoo[/url]

item.title: Window Manager summary (Flux, Gnome, KDE)
item.dc:creator: @Stork Stork
item.description:
@Stork wrote:

Switched to flux on my shite laptop and increased the resolution to 1280x1024, it still feels quite a bit faster then gnome did.

Read full topic

item.title: Window Manager summary (Flux, Gnome, KDE)
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

sppt:

yeah, XFCE is kinda in between, it has niceness, and is pretty light ^.^

To me XFCE seems like a Gnome + KDE hybrid, except it is much more light weight.

I still prefer KDE.

Read full topic

item.title: Window Manager summary (Flux, Gnome, KDE)
item.dc:creator: @Stork Stork
item.description:
@Stork wrote:

Gnome is more lightweight then KDE but less then fluxbox. Like I said.

Can’t say I’ve ever used XFCE, but it probably ranks between flux and gnome.

Read full topic

@sppt wrote:

Gnome is a fairly lightweight window manager. It's simplistic and doesn't really have many resource-guzzling effects.

AFAIK gnome isnt that ‘fairly’ lightweight, and yeah, what about xfce ?

item.title: Window Manager summary (Flux, Gnome, KDE)
item.dc:creator: @Stork Stork
item.description:
@Stork wrote:

The three most popular window managers are Fluxbox, Gnome, and KDE. Whichever you choose is just a matter of personal preference. Here’s a few details about each one to stop all this bullshit about window managers.
In order of resources used, Flux is by far the lightest, followed by Gnome, with KDE using the most resources.

[size=10pt]Gnome[/size]
Gnome is a fairly lightweight window manager. It’s simplistic and doesn’t really have many resource-guzzling effects.
Screenshots:
Gnome on Ubuntu
Another Gnome on Ubuntu
Gnome on Gentoo

[size=10pt]KDE[/size]
KDE has a lot more features then gnome, and thus uses more system resources, which is fine provided you have them to spare
Screenshots:
KDE on Ubuntu (Kubuntu)
KDE on Gentoo

[size=10pt]Fluxbox[/size]
Fluxbox is amazingly lightweight and very configurable. Perfect if you don’t have much RAM.
Screenshots:
Fluxbox on Ubuntu
Fluxbox on Gentoo
